thread.title: Protesters Decry Trump Immigration Orders at Washington Square Park Rally
thread.title_full: Protesters Decry Trump Immigration Orders at Washington Square Park Rally

title: Protesters Decry Trump Immigration Orders at Washington Square Park Rally

organizations.name: rally protesters decry trump immigration orders

text:
Protesters Decry Trump Immigration Orders at Washington Square Park Rally By Danielle Tcholakian | January 25, 2017 5:51pm View Full Caption DNAinfo/Noah Hurowitz 
GREENWICH VILLAGE — Crowds gathered at Washington Square Park Wednesday evening to protest President Donald Trump's recent executive orders. 
The president moved this week to restrict people from select countries with large Muslim populations from entering the United States, to build a wall along the border of Mexico and to cut federal funds to "sanctuary cities" like New York that don't cooperate with deportations and other federal actions against undocumented immigrants. 
"Say it loud, say it clear, refugees are welcome here," the crowd chanted. Protesters at the front of the Washington Square Park rally pic.twitter.com/LNQ4NI58IG — Danielle Tcholakian (@danielleiat) January 25, 2017 
The protest was organized quickly by the New York chapter of the Council on American-Islamic Relations (CAIR-NY). 
The executive order barring travel from countries with large Muslim populations targets Iran, Iraq, Libya, Somalia, Sudan, Syria and Yemen. 
It does not include Egypt, Turkey or Saudi Arabia, where the Trump family has business endeavors. 
The executive order on sanctuary cities specified that cities that declare themselves “sanctuaries” for immigrants, as New York City has, will be ineligible to receive federal grants, other than those “deemed necessary for law enforcement purposes.” 
► READ MORE: New York Could Lose Billions as Trump Attacks Sanctuary Cities 
Comptroller Scott Stringer previously estimated Trump could impact a total of $7 billion that the city relies on from the federal government. 
The majority of that funding goes to the NYPD's counterterrorism efforts — more than 61 percent of which is funded by the federal government — and to services for the city's neediest denizens, including child protective services, affordable housing and HIV/AIDS prevention. 
The sanctuary cities order also states that the Trump administration plans to release a weekly report of “criminal actions committed by aliens and any [city] that ignored or otherwise failed to honor” the efforts of federal immigration authorities. 
New York City is one of several cities around the country that has pledged not to cooperate with federal immigration officials.
